content.title: Cluster Headache
content.summary: Cluster headache is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral orbital/periorbital pain with ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion). Attacks occur in clusters lasting weeks to months, with pain-free remission periods. Treatment involves high-flow oxygen and triptans for acute attacks, with verapamil as first-line prevention.
key_points: Severe unilateral orbital/periorbital pain lasting 15-180 minutes
Ipsilateral autonomic features: Lacrimation, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, ptosis, miosis
Circadian pattern: Attacks often at same time daily, frequently nocturnal
Male predominance (3:1); smoking is major risk factor
Acute: High-flow oxygen (12-15 L/min) or sumatriptan SC/nasal
Prevention: Verapamil first-line; galcanezumab approved for episodic cluster
content.statement: Cluster headache is a severe unilateral headache with autonomic features occurring in clusters, treated acutely with oxygen or triptans and prevented with verapamil.

explanation.intuition: Think of cluster headache as an 'alarm clock' headache that strikes like clockwork at the same time each day during a cluster period. The trigeminal nerve fires causing excruciating pain around the eye, while the parasympathetic system activates causing tearing and nasal congestion. Unlike migraineurs who lie still in dark rooms, cluster patients pace restlessly because movement doesn't worsen the pain.
explanation.key_insight: Cluster headache is often called 'suicide headache' due to its severity. The KEY distinguishing feature is RESTLESSNESS during attacks - patients pace, rock, or bang their heads. Migraineurs prefer to lie still. Also, cluster has IPSILATERAL autonomic features while migraine may have bilateral or no autonomic symptoms.
explanation.technical_details: Hypothalamic activation (posterior hypothalamus) drives circadian periodicity. Trigeminovascular activation causes pain. Parasympathetic activation (superior salivatory nucleus) causes autonomic features. Functional imaging shows ipsilateral posterior hypothalamic activation during attacks.

definitions_glossary.cluster_headache: Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia with severe unilateral pain and ipsilateral autonomic features
definitions_glossary.trigeminal_autonomic_cephalalgia: Primary headache disorders with trigeminal pain and cranial autonomic symptoms
definitions_glossary.autonomic_features: Lacrimation, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, ptosis, miosis, eyelid edema
definitions_glossary.episodic_cluster: Cluster periods lasting 7 days to 1 year with remissions ≥3 months
definitions_glossary.chronic_cluster: No remission >3 months for at least 1 year
definitions_glossary.cluster_period: Time frame (weeks-months) during which attacks occur
definitions_glossary.circadian_pattern: Attacks occurring at predictable times, often nocturnal
definitions_glossary.Horner_syndrome: Partial: miosis and ptosis from sympathetic involvement
definitions_glossary.galcanezumab: CGRP monoclonal antibody approved for episodic cluster headache

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hypothalamic dysfunction drives circadian periodicity; trigeminal nerve activation causes pain; parasympathetic activation causes autonomic features

neural_pathways.pain: Trigeminal afferents from periorbital region → trigeminal nucleus caudalis
neural_pathways.autonomic: Trigeminal-autonomic reflex via superior salivatory nucleus → sphenopalatine ganglion

ICHD_3_criteria.B: Severe unilateral orbital, supraorbital, or temporal pain lasting 15-180 min
ICHD_3_criteria.C: Either or both: (1) Ipsilateral autonomic feature (lacrimation, nasal congestion, conjunctival injection, eyelid edema, forehead sweating, miosis, ptosis); (2) Sense of restlessness or agitation
ICHD_3_criteria.D: Attacks occur from every other day to 8 per day

clinical_features: Excruciating severity (patients describe as 'worst pain imaginable')
Circadian pattern (often nocturnal, 90 min after sleep onset)

differential_diagnosis: Migraine (bilateral possible, longer attacks, lying still preferred)
Paroxysmal hemicrania (shorter attacks, absolute indomethacin response)

acute.oxygen: High-flow 100% O2 at 12-15 L/min via non-rebreather for 15-20 min; 70% effective
acute.sumatriptan: 6mg SC (fastest) or 20mg nasal spray; 75% effective within 15 min
acute.avoid: Oral triptans (too slow for short attacks)

transitional.corticosteroids: Prednisone burst to break cluster while starting prevention

preventive.first_line: Verapamil 240-960 mg/day (ECG monitoring for heart block)
preventive.surgical: Deep brain stimulation or sphenopalatine ganglion stimulation for refractory

definition.@value: A trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral periorbital pain with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms, occurring in clusters with remission periods between

scopeNote.@value: Covers diagnosis, acute treatment, and prevention of cluster headache

medicalCode.description: Cluster headaches and other trigeminal autonomic cephalgias

learning_objectives: Describe classic clinical features of cluster headache including autonomic symptoms
Differentiate cluster headache from migraine and other TACs
Apply acute treatment with oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan
Select appropriate preventive therapy with verapamil
Recognize indications for transitional therapy during cluster onset
clinical_pearls: RESTLESSNESS during attacks = cluster; lying still = migraine
High-flow oxygen 12-15 L/min is FIRST LINE - faster than triptans
Oral triptans too slow - use SC or nasal for short attacks
Verapamil doses often >240mg; need ECG monitoring (heart block)
Alcohol triggers attacks ONLY during cluster period, not remission
common_misconceptions: Cluster headache is 'just a bad migraine' - completely different pathophysiology and treatment
Pain medications help - opioids ineffective, delay proper treatment
Cluster affects both sides - always strictly unilateral
